text: When you're building a category, you need to make sure that there is a category that's validated by analysts and directory sites and things like that. But also, you want to have a lot of traction in terms of thought leadership like why is this the category? What are the unique value propositions of this particular thing? What are the pain points it solves? And then of course, getting a lot of content around because when you're generating a new category, you're also needing to educate buyers that there is a category that they can now budget for and why they should allocate budget for that.
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks Barbra about the tactical process of category creation - what steps companies need to take when trying to establish a new product category. Barbra explains that building a new product category requires validation from industry analysts like Gartner and directory sites like G2 Crowd, but also demands significant thought leadership and content marketing efforts. She emphasizes that when creating a new category, you're not just marketing a product but educating the entire market about why this category should exist and deserve budget allocation.
vocabulary_highlights: traction in terms of thought leadership
text_ko: 카테고리(category)를 만들 때는 애널리스트(analysts)나 디렉터리 사이트(directory sites) 같은 곳에서 검증된 카테고리가 있는지 확인해야 해요. 동시에 ‘왜 이게 카테고리인가’에 대한 답을 제시할 수 있는 사고 리더십(thought leadership) 측면에서 충분한 트랙션(traction)이 있어야 하고, 이게 제공하는 고유한 가치 제안(unique value propositions)은 무엇인지, 어떤 고충(pain points)을 해결하는지도 분명히 해야 해요. 그리고 당연히 관련 콘텐츠를 많이 만들어야 해요. 새로운 카테고리를 만들면 구매자(buyers)들에게 그 카테고리가 존재한다는 것과 왜 그걸 위해 예산(budget)을 배정해야 하는지 교육해야 하니까요.
text_zh: 当你在打造一个新品类的时候，你得确保这个品类能得到分析师和各种目录网站的认可。但同时呢，你也要在思想领导力(thought leadership)方面下功夫，比如说为什么会有这个品类？这个东西的独特价值主张(unique value propositions)是什么？它能解决哪些痛点？然后当然了，还要做大量的内容，因为你在创造一个全新品类的时候，其实也需要教育买家，让他们知道现在有这么个品类可以做预算了，以及为什么应该给这个品类分配预算。
text_es: Cuando estás creando una categoría, tienes que asegurarte de que sea una categoría validada por analistas y sitios de directorios y todo eso. Pero también necesitas tener mucha tracción en términos de liderazgo de pensamiento (thought leadership), o sea, ¿por qué esta es LA categoría? ¿Cuáles son las propuestas de valor únicas de esto en particular? ¿Qué puntos de dolor resuelve? Y después, claro, generar un montón de contenido porque cuando estás creando una nueva categoría, también necesitas educar a los compradores de que existe una categoría para la cual ya pueden presupuestar y por qué deberían asignar presupuesto para eso.
key_sentence: Building a category requires traction in terms of thought leadership and unique value propositions.

text: We tried several things. One of the main things that we zeroed in on was recruiting optimization platform, and it was really like we are doing that. We're helping companies really structure the process, identify where they have gaps, where people are falling through the cracks, where they're flying through the process and really tweak and iterate it and improve it.
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks Barbra about Greenhouse's failed attempt at category creation. Barbra explains how they tried to move away from the negatively perceived ATS (Applicant Tracking System) category by creating a new category called 'recruiting optimization platform.' She describes how they positioned Greenhouse as helping companies optimize their recruiting processes by identifying inefficiencies and gaps in their hiring workflows, rather than just being another transactional applicant tracking system.
text_ko: 저희가 여러 가지를 시도해 봤어요. 그중에 집중한 핵심 중 하나가 채용 최적화 플랫폼(recruiting optimization platform)이었고, 사실 말 그대로 그걸 실행하고 있어요. 기업들이 채용 프로세스를 체계화하고 어디에 허점이 있는지, 지원자가 어디서 빠져나가는지, 어떤 단계는 너무 빨리 지나가는지 등을 찾아내 세부적으로 조정하고 반복해서 개선할 수 있도록 도와드려요.
text_zh: 我们试了好多种做法。其中一个重点就是招聘优化平台(recruiting optimization platform)，这个确实是我们在做的事儿。我们帮公司把整个流程梳理清楚，找出哪儿有漏洞，哪些人才被漏掉了，哪些环节走得太快，然后不断地调整优化，让整个招聘流程越来越好。
text_es: Probamos varias cosas. Una de las principales en las que nos enfocamos fue una plataforma de optimización de reclutamiento, y era exactamente lo que estábamos haciendo. Estamos ayudando a las empresas a estructurar bien el proceso, a identificar dónde tienen huecos, dónde se les están escapando candidatos, dónde la gente pasa muy rápido por el proceso, y realmente ajustarlo, ir mejorándolo paso a paso.
key_sentence: We zeroed in on recruiting optimization to identify gaps and improve processes.

text: So it didn't really make sense to continue to go against the grain of, no, we're going to be this new thing or we're going to call it this if everybody, even seeing the value and seeing the differentiation of our platform to others, still called it an ATS. We abandoned that process. But I think the main thing that we understood then was instead of spending the time and money to build a new category, we were going to spend the time and money to elevate the value of this category.
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny is learning about when category creation fails and companies should pivot their approach. Barbra explains how Greenhouse ultimately abandoned their attempt to create the 'recruiting optimization platform' category because customers kept referring to their product as an ATS despite understanding its superior value. Instead of fighting market perception, they decided to elevate and transform the existing ATS category by making it more strategic and valuable to users.
text_ko: 그래서 '우리가 이걸 완전히 새로운 것으로 만들겠다'거나 '이렇게 불러야겠다'며 억지로 밀고 가는 건 의미가 없겠다고 판단했어요. 사람들이 우리 플랫폼의 가치와 차별성은 알아봐도, 여전히 지원자 추적 시스템(applicant tracking system, ATS)이라고 부르는 경우가 많았거든요. 그래서 그 시도는 접었어요. 대신 그때 우리가 깨달은 핵심은, 새로운 카테고리를 만들기 위해 시간과 돈을 쓰기보다는 그 카테고리의 가치를 끌어올리는 데 시간과 자원을 쓰겠다는 거였어요.
text_zh: 所以继续跟大家对着干其实没什么意义，我们非要说自己是个全新的东西，非要给它起个新名字，但实际上大家都看得出我们平台的价值和跟其他家的差异化，可还是叫它ATS。我们就不再坚持那套了。但我觉得最主要的是，我们当时明白了，与其花时间和钱去打造一个新品类，不如把这些时间和钱用来提升这个品类的价值。
text_es: Entonces realmente no tenía sentido seguir yendo contra la corriente, diciendo "no, vamos a ser algo nuevo" o "lo vamos a llamar de otra forma" si todo el mundo, aun viendo el valor y la diferenciación de nuestra plataforma respecto a otras, seguía llamándolo un ATS. Abandonamos ese proceso. Pero creo que lo principal que entendimos entonces fue que en lugar de gastar el tiempo y el dinero en crear una nueva categoría, íbamos a invertir ese tiempo y dinero en elevar el valor de esta categoría.
key_sentence: We abandoned that process to elevate the value of the existing category instead.

text: And so visual collaboration was our way of putting a nice bow around this thing that could then be an enterprise product that solves a lot of different problems for a lot of different use cases and different types of users. We started out selling and having a lot of users that were in product and in engineering and teams that were used to using whiteboards anyway and then needed to do it in a distributed way, but very quickly packaged different types of jobs for HR teams or marketing teams or design teams and pretty much anybody in the organization.
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks about how Miro successfully created the visual collaboration category when there wasn't existing budget for it. Barbra explains how 'visual collaboration' served as an umbrella term that unified Miro's diverse use cases across different teams and departments. She describes how they started with core users in product and engineering who already understood whiteboarding, then expanded to package the platform for various other teams throughout organizations.
text_ko: 그래서 비주얼 협업(visual collaboration)은 이걸 깔끔하게 포장해 주는 방식이었고, 그게 결국 다양한 사용 사례(use cases)와 여러 유형의 사용자들이 겪는 여러 문제를 해결하는 엔터프라이즈 제품(enterprise product)이 되게 해줬어요. 처음에는 제품팀과 엔지니어링팀에서 일하는 분들, 원래부터 화이트보드를 쓰던 팀들이 주된 사용자였고 원격으로도 같은 작업을 해야 해서 쓰기 시작했어요. 그런데 생각보다 빨리 인사(HR)팀이나 마케팅팀, 디자인팀 같은 다른 직무용 패키지도 만들게 되었고, 결국 조직 내 거의 누구나 쓸 수 있는 도구가 되었어요.
text_zh: 所以可视化协作(visual collaboration)就是我们把这个东西包装得漂漂亮亮的方式，让它能成为一个企业级产品，解决各种不同用户在各种不同场景下的各种问题。我们一开始主要是卖给产品和工程团队的用户，这些团队本来就习惯用白板，现在需要远程协作的方式来做，但很快我们就针对HR团队、市场团队、设计团队包装出了不同类型的解决方案，基本上公司里任何部门都能用。
text_es: Y entonces la colaboración visual fue nuestra manera de darle el toque final a esto que luego podría convertirse en un producto empresarial que resolviera un montón de problemas diferentes para muchos casos de uso distintos y diferentes tipos de usuarios. Empezamos vendiendo y teniendo muchos usuarios que estaban en producto y en ingeniería, equipos que ya estaban acostumbrados a usar pizarras blancas (whiteboards) y que necesitaban hacerlo de forma distribuida, pero muy rápido empaquetamos diferentes tipos de trabajos para equipos de RR.HH. o equipos de marketing o equipos de diseño y prácticamente cualquier persona de la organización.
key_sentence: Visual collaboration puts a nice bow around an enterprise product for diverse use cases.

text: All of my best marketing and positioning literally comes from having a million conversations with customers and listening to how they solve problems and how our system helps them solve problems and what they're doing and how they talk about stuff. I think that's step one, is really understanding who those buyers are, how they talk about the product, what's the unique differentiator and selling points?
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks for tactical advice about the category creation process for founders who want to explore this approach. Barbra emphasizes that successful marketing and positioning starts with extensive customer research and understanding exactly how customers describe their problems and solutions. She stresses that the foundation of category creation is deeply understanding buyer language, pain points, and how they naturally talk about the product's value proposition.
text_ko: 사실 제 최고의 마케팅과 포지셔닝(marketing and positioning)은 말 그대로 고객들과의 셀 수 없이 많은 대화에서 나와요. 그들이 문제를 어떻게 해결하는지, 우리 시스템이 그걸 어떻게 돕는지, 그들이 무슨 일을 하고 어떻게 말하는지를 귀 기울여 듣는 거예요. 제 생각엔 그게 첫 번째 단계예요 — 누가 그 구매자들(buyers)인지, 그들이 제품을 어떻게 표현하는지, 차별화 요소(unique differentiator)와 판매 포인트(selling points)가 뭔지 진짜로 이해하는 것 말이에요.
text_zh: 我所有最好的营销和定位策略，说白了就是跟客户聊了无数次，听他们怎么解决问题，我们的系统怎么帮他们解决问题，看他们平时都在做什么，听他们怎么表达这些事儿。我觉得第一步就是要真正搞清楚这些买家是谁，他们怎么谈论产品，我们的独特差异化(differentiator)和卖点(selling points)到底是什么？
text_es: Todo mi mejor marketing y posicionamiento viene literalmente de tener miles de conversaciones con clientes y escuchar cómo resuelven sus problemas, cómo nuestro sistema les ayuda a solucionarlos, qué están haciendo y cómo hablan de las cosas. Creo que ese es el primer paso: realmente entender quiénes son esos compradores, cómo hablan del producto, cuál es el diferenciador único y los puntos de venta clave.
key_sentence: Best marketing comes from having a million conversations to understand unique differentiators.

text: I almost didn't join because it was called RealtimeBoard. Honestly, I was like, 'Oh my, god. This is so literal.' While I was walking the dogs with my husband, I'm like, 'Am I really going to join a company called RealtimeBoard? Can this be a big company with that name?' I was really concerned about it and ultimately, I spent more time with the leaders there and I was like, 'Okay, I think they'll be open to changing the name.'
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks about how to know when it's time to rebrand a product. Barbra shares her personal experience of nearly rejecting the Miro opportunity because of concerns about the original name 'RealtimeBoard.' She explains how the overly literal and descriptive name made her question whether the company could scale to become a major enterprise player, and how she made the potential rebrand a condition of joining the company.
text_ko: RealtimeBoard라는 이름 때문에 거의 합류 안 할 뻔했어요. 솔직히 '세상에, 이름이 너무 문자 그대로네' 싶었거든요. 남편이랑 강아지 데리고 산책하면서도 '진짜 RealtimeBoard라는 회사에 들어갈까? 그런 이름으로 큰 회사가 될 수 있을까?' 하고 계속 고민했어요. 정말 걱정됐는데, 결국 거기 리더분들이랑 시간을 더 보내보니 '아, 이름 바꾸는 것에 대해 열려 있겠구나' 싶더라고요.
text_zh: 我当时差点没加入，因为公司叫RealtimeBoard。说实话，我当时想，"天哪，这名字也太直白了吧。" 我和老公遛狗的时候还在想，"我真的要加入一家叫RealtimeBoard的公司吗？就这个名字，能做成大公司吗？" 我真的很担心这个问题，后来跟那边的领导们接触多了，我想，"好吧，他们应该会愿意改名字的。"
text_es: Por poco no me uno porque se llamaba RealtimeBoard. En serio, yo pensaba 'Ay, Dios mío. Qué nombre tan literal.' Mientras paseaba a los perros con mi marido, le decía '¿De verdad me voy a meter a una empresa que se llama RealtimeBoard? ¿Puede ser una empresa grande con ese nombre?' Me preocupaba mucho el tema y al final, pasé más tiempo con los líderes de allá y dije 'Bueno, creo que van a estar abiertos a cambiar el nombre.'
key_sentence: I was concerned about the name RealtimeBoard but leaders were open to changing it.

text: The best way to incorporate your brand and how people are interacting with people that you are selling to, customers or whoever, partners, is to have those values incorporated because then it's every touchpoint isn't something that you have to train people, okay, these are all the touch points and this is how the brand needs to manifest. It already will because it's part of the DNA of the company.
speaker: Barbra Gago
context: Lenny asks for examples of how company values can inform brand decisions and customer interactions. Barbra explains her philosophy that the strongest brands integrate company values so deeply into their DNA that brand expression becomes automatic across all customer touchpoints. She argues that when values are truly embedded in company culture, employees naturally embody the brand without extensive training because the values guide their authentic behavior.
text_ko: 브랜드(brand)와 고객이나 파트너 같은 판매 대상과의 상호작용을 제대로 녹여내는 가장 좋은 방법은 그 가치를 조직에 내재화하는 거예요. 그래야 매번 각 터치포인트(touchpoint)마다 사람들을 따로 교육하면서 “여기는 이렇게 해야 해요”라고 일일이 설명할 필요가 없어요. 브랜드가 어떻게 표현(manifest)되어야 하는지는 이미 회사 DNA(company DNA)에 배어 있어서 자연스럽게 드러나거든요.
text_zh: 要让品牌真正融入到你和客户、合作伙伴这些人的互动中，最好的办法就是把这些价值观真正植入进去。这样一来，每个接触点(touchpoint)都不用你去特意培训员工说"这些是接触点，品牌要这样体现"，因为这已经成了公司的DNA，自然而然就会体现出来。
text_es: La mejor manera de integrar tu marca y cómo la gente interactúa con las personas a las que les vendes - clientes, socios, quien sea - es tener esos valores ya incorporados. Porque así, cada punto de contacto (touchpoint) no es algo que tengas que andar enseñando a la gente: "mira, estos son todos los puntos de contacto y así es como la marca se tiene que manifestar." Ya va a salir natural porque forma parte del ADN de la empresa.
key_sentence: Incorporating values ensures every touchpoint reflects the brand's DNA without additional training.
